keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen is approaching the Philippine island of Catanduanes, prompting the evacuation of over 9,000 residents due to the risk of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high.

Catanduanes, with a population of 270,000, is a frequently affected island due to its location in the path of western Pacific cyclones and has historically been the first landmass impacted by such storms.
The Philippines experiences an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, often affecting impoverished communities in disaster-prone areas.
Scientists have linked increasing storm intensity to human-driven climate change, suggesting that climate change is exacerbating the severity of tropical storms.

The country is still recovering from previous disasters, including a magnitude 6.9 and 7.4 earthquake in Cebu and southern Philippines, which killed dozens and triggered tsunami warnings, adding to public anxiety and infrastructure strain.
Evacuations in Catanduanes are part of a recurring drill, indicating preparedness efforts that are both routine and critical for saving lives in high-risk zones.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of residents in the Philippine island of Catanduanes have evacuated their homes as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches, with forecasted gusts of up to 80km/h and a risk of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high. The evacuation is part of a regular drill, as Catanduanes is often the first landmass affected by cyclones in the western Pacific. The storm comes amid a period of ongoing disaster strain in the Philippines, following recent deadly earthquakes in Cebu and southern regions, as well as Typhoon Ragasa in September. Scientists emphasize that climate change is intensifying storm patterns, making extreme weather events more frequent and severe in disaster-prone areas like the Philippines.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
